page.title: 18Bookham's recreational areas
page.content:
Most residents have pleasant gardens, some with swimming-pools. They also have easy access to open countryside. Bookham Common is mainly wooded (oaks provided pannage for swine in 1086). The first fish ponds created by Chertsey Abbey survive, and there are small fishing ponds in Eastwick. The National Trust has used volunteers to clear ponds & scrub on the Common.
Surrey County Council has just produced a plan to increase the use of {Norbury Park}for casual recreation and education. They plan to manage the wood and farmland to re-establish open downland & improve public access. Local residents using it to exercise their dogs oppose the plan, fearing an influx of people and 'hot dog' vans. Others welcome the idea of a country park.
